did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Diego Cortez No Wave Collection, circa 1972-1981.
did.physdesc: Photographs, artwork, correspondence, manuscripts, and printed material.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Approximately 135 pieces complied by Diego Cortez comprising of material related to both his 1981 No Wave show at PS1 and many of the personalities involved in the artistic and musical scenes of the period, including Jimmy DeSana, James Chance, Anya Phillips, Fab 5 Freddy, Bob Gruen, Robert Gordon, Glenn O'Brien, Legs O'Neil, Ray Johnson, Debbie Harry, and Jean-Michel Basquiat, among others. The collection also contains concert flyers, photographs, and exhibition materials, including early proposals for a book and exhibition on graffiti art.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Born James Allen Curtis in Geneva, Illinois in 1946, Curtis moved to New York City in 1973 and assumed the name Diego Cortez. He became well-known as an artist, club manager, promoter, and independent curator, co-founding the influential NYC nightspot The Mudd Club, which offered an eclectic mix of art, music and cultural events that combined both modernist and punk aesthetics. In 1981, Cortez curated the groundbreaking exhibition "New York, No Wave" at a defunct elementary school in Long Island City, Queens called P.S. 1. The exhibition featured the work of David Byrne, Keith Haring, Robert Mapplethorpe, Jean-Michel Basquiat, and Kenny Scharf, among many others.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Approximately 135 pieces complied by Diego Cortez comprising of material related to both his 1981 No Wave show at PS1 and many of the personalities involved in the artistic and musical scenes of the period, including Jimmy DeSana, James Chance, Anya Phillips, Fab 5 Freddy, Bob Gruen, Robert Gordon, Glenn O'Brien, Legs O'Neil, Ray Johnson, Debbie Harry, and Jean-Michel Basquiat, among others. The collection also contains concert flyers, photographs, and exhibition materials, including early proposals for a book and exhibition on graffiti art.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Diego Cortez No Wave Collection, #8120. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

did.unittitle: Letter by Marina Abramovic to Diego Cortez
did.physdesc: Typed letter with signature and flower drawing in ink, written from Belgrade, Yugoslavia. Marina invites Cortez to participate in 'April Meeting' performance festival in Belgrade.

did.unittitle: Handwritten letter from Jimmy DeSana to Diego Cortez
did.physdesc: Red ink on paper, signed by DeSana with artist's stamp of camera/hands at top. With envelope with 'CORTEZ' handwritten on it.

did.unittitle: Postcard to Diego and Jim DeSana from "cf"
Letter by Liz Rhodes to Diego Cortez
did.physdesc: Two-sided handwritten letter with signature, written from London, with notations by Cortez. At the behest of Peter Gidal, Rhodes invites Cortez to show films at the London Film Cooperative.

did.unittitle: Letter to DC from Udo Breger
did.physdesc: One page letter with attached photograph of Breger.

scopecontent.p: DC met Breger through William S. Burroughs. Breger was the editor of the Swiss Journal SOFT NEED.

did.unittitle: Letter to DC c/o Betsy Sussler from Udo Breger
did.physdesc: Two small pages, one with attached photo of Breger. In postmarked envelope.

did.unittitle: Letter by Peter Gidal to "Hernando Cortez"

scopecontent.p: Experimental filmmaker Peter Gidal also head of London Filmmakers Cooperative. Aerogramme letter by Gidal from London re: possible film screenings by DC in London.

did.unittitle: Letter by Norman Rosenthal to Diego Cortez
did.physdesc: Two-sided handwritten letter by Rosenthal from London. Signature on verso.

scopecontent.p: He sums up the state of affairs at the I.C.A. and other venues in London.

did.unittitle: Letter from Pasquale Trisorio to Diego

scopecontent.p: Re: film screening at Galeria Wspolszesna

did.unittitle: Letter by Zbigniew Makarewicz to Consulate General of Poland to the US

scopecontent.p: Requesting artistic visa for Cortez re: a film screening in Warsaw.
Re: film screening at Galeria Wspolszensna, Warsaw

did.unittitle: Typed letter by Diego Cortez to Candida HÃ¶ffer

scopecontent.p: Re: Cortez's upcoming 'SMEAR' exhibition at Konrad Fischer Gallery, Dusseldorf.

did.unittitle: Letter by Diego Cortez to Robin Winters
did.physdesc: Two-sided typed letter with handwritten notations in ink, written from Germany.

scopecontent.p: Cortez brings Winters up to date on several European projects.

did.unittitle: Postcard from Ingrid Oppenheim to DC

scopecontent.p: "Greetings from Ingrid Oppenheim [Koln gallerist]." DC met Oppenheim through Dennis Oppenheim, for whom DC first worked for in NYC in 1973-74.

did.physdesc: Handwritten. In handwritten envelope "Por Diego Cortez."

scopecontent.p: DeSana brings DC up to date on all recent affairs, including the fact that DC ex-roommate Jane Kaplowitz will now move in with historian Robert Rosenblum. DeSana and DC always referred to each other as 'Doctor' and here refers to Jane as 'Nurse.' Also gossip about art critics David Bourdon and Gregory Battcock.

did.unittitle: Postcard from UK to Diego Cortez

scopecontent.p: From Michael Zilkha and Michel Esteban to Cortez, Ze Records.
Calling card.

did.unittitle: Draft of a letter to Yossy Aoren

scopecontent.p: Regarding possible show in Israel.

did.unittitle: MoMA security guard notes for 1975 'Xerox and Blood' exhibition
did.physdesc: Photograph contact sheet, notebook pages, handwritten in ink, typed letter from Head of MoMA security on MoMA stationary, bank deposit slip, MoMA check stub, note card, etc.

scopecontent.p: Cortez was employed as a security guard at MoMA in 1974-75. He was invited to make a show at the Whitney Museum Art Resources Center. The exhibition was titled 'Xerox and Blood' and opened in Spring, 1975. Cortez's made several conceptual wall series which dealt with the issues of security and art. One series reflects on the attack on Picasso's Guernica by artist Tony Shafrazi.

did.unittitle: Images taken at MoMA security office
did.physdesc: One photo contact sheet, including arrest pictures of Tony Shafrazi.

30 assorted handwritten-in-ink notebook pages from MoMA security work for Whitney Downtown Museum exhibition by Cortez (most written on both sides); one check stub, one deposit slip, one letter on MoMA letterhead from Head of Security Dept.

did.unittitle: Works from 1975 Whitney Downtown Museum show
Announcements for 1975 "Xerox and Blood" show at Whitney Downtown Museum
Installation plan for 1975 Whitney Downtown Museum show

scopecontent.p: Installation plan.

did.unittitle: Notes for photo series 'Cataratta Riflesso Rosso' for 1976 Galleria Trisorio exhibition
Sketches for wall paintings for 1976 'Cataratta Riflesso Rosso' exhibition, Galleria Trisorio
did.physdesc: Red and blue inks on found letterhead. Nine pages.

did.unittitle: Sketches, notes re: medical photo works in "Cataratta Riflesso Rosso"

scopecontent.p: Exhibition at Studio Pasquale Trisorio

did.unittitle: Prints documenting Cortez's gallery exhibition 'Cataratta Riflesso Rosso' at Galleria Trisorio
did.physdesc: Contact prints. Both stamped by del Monaco on verso and numbered by pencil.

did.unittitle: Smear, The Batman Show, and Hospital Colors

scopecontent.p: 3 original slides used in Cortez's lecture/performance 'Hospital Colors' performed at 'April Meeting' in Belgrade (1975) and Artists Space, NYC (1976). The lecture analyzed the chromatics of institutional interiors.

did.unittitle: Study for announcement card for Diego Cortez "SMEAR" exhibition

scopecontent.p: Galerie Konrad Fischer.

did.unittitle: Two-sided handwritten note by Diego Cortez

scopecontent.p: Note is earliest formulation of the future 1981 'New York/New Wave' show at PS1. Ink and typed text on paper card.

This was the first exhibition which Cortez curated as well as the first exhibition sponsored by Collaborative Projects (COLAB). The exhibition took place at Robin Winters loft in Soho. These are the only notes documenting the organization of that show. Xerox. Signed.

did.physdesc: Collage, mirror mounted on red construction paper.

scopecontent.p: Johnson's submission to Cortez's 1977 exhibition 'The Batman Show', sponsored by Collaborative Projects (Colab), held at Robin Winters' Soho loft in 1977. Hand printed title and artist's stamp on face of work.

did.unittitle: Initial List of Artists, "New York/New Wave" exhibition (1981)

did.physdesc: Signed and titled with notations on verso (handwritten specs as to larger print to be made for 'New York/New Wave show, dated '1980').

scopecontent.p: From the New York/New Wave exhibition
2 unique hand-colored Polaroids. These two photographs were exhibited in Cortez's 1981 'New York/New Wave' exhibition at P.S.1.

did.physdesc: Photocopy with hand-written edits and notations by Cortez. 13 pages.

did.unittitle: Graffiti 1980, America's Underground Art Come of Age, Subterranean Calligraphy, 1981 | From Steel to Canvas, The Graffiti 1980 Experience, Zoo York Magazine, 1980
did.physdesc: Two typewritten manuscripts on Graffiti. 10 pages.
Blue envelope with hand-written title by Cortez.

did.unittitle: Original Proposal Notes for Unrealized Graffiti Exhibition Project, Spring
Notes for screenings in European cinematheque tour by Cortez

scopecontent.p: At the behest of Jonas Mekas and P. Adams Sitney, Cortez made a tour of European cinematheques and showed a series of films made for the analytic projector which converts a film screening into a 'film performance'. Red ink and black marker on found letterhead with visual diagrams of stills from films

did.unittitle: Notes for screenings in European cinematheque tour by Cortez

scopecontent.p: At the behest of Jonas Mekas and P. Adams Sitney, Cortez made a tour of European cinematheques and showed a series of films made for the analytic projector which converts a film screening into a 'film performance'. Red ink and black marker on found letterhead with visual diagrams of stills from films.

did.physdesc: One-page typed notes on Brussels letterhead

scopecontent.p: re: DC 1975-76 European and US tour of exhibitions, performances and film screenings (not all realized).

did.unittitle: Bio and Notes on Screening for Candida Hoffer

scopecontent.p: Re: Cortez's upcoming 'SMEAR' exhibition at Konrad Fischer Gallery, Dusseldorf.
Including cues. Analytic projector film to be screened in US and Europe. Two pages, Xerox with handwritten notes.

did.unittitle: Notes re: possible programming of films by Diego Cortez

scopecontent.p: Notes on analytic projector specifications and DC biography. Stadtmuseum.

did.unittitle: Notes re: "New American Performance" proposal for Stadtische Kunsthalle

controlaccess.corpname: Beach Books, Distributed by City Lights

scopecontent.p: These notes were made for an unrealized artist book commissioned by Mario Diacono, Bologna. 4 typewritten pages with handwritten notes in ink and pencil.

did.unittitle: Storyboads for William S. Burroughs film project, Blade Runner

scopecontent.p: Extracts from Burroughs' text with notations and collage elements by Cortez, mounted on drawing paper pad. In 1979, Cortez asked Burroughs and his assistant, James Grauerholz, for the film rights for the book and was granted permission. The film was never realized. Burroughs' book is a sci-fi novella which began as a story treatment for a proposed film adaptation of Alan E. Nourse's novel 'The Bladerunner.' Burroughs' treatment has been described as a closet screenplay. It is set in the early 21st century and involves mutated viruses and a medical-care apocalypse. The term 'blade runner' refers to a smuggler of medical supplies, e.g. scalpels. No film was ever made from Burroughs' text. The title was later bought by Ridley Scott for use in his 1982 science fiction film, 'Blade Runner.' Its plot was based on Philip K. Dick's 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?' and not the Nourse/ Burroughs material, although the dialogue incorporates the term 'blade runner' into dialogue.

scopecontent.p: With participation of Diego Cortez ('Notes on Painter/Patient Performance') and other artists. Joseph Beuys on cover.

scopecontent.p: Made while Cortez was in MFA program at the School of the Art institute of Chicago. Kodak photo paper. Stmaped and titled by DC on verso.
Gift of artist to Diego Cortez. This photo was taken at Charlotte Moorman's Avant Garde Festival at Grand Central Station.

did.physdesc: Artist's stamp and date on verso.

scopecontent.p: "101 Nudes" model.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Bobby Daren with Marie Keller

scopecontent.p: Marie Keller would later married Duchamp scholar, Francis M. Naumann. Keller, Naumann and DC were close friends while studying at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (1971-73).
Unknown photographer.

Unknown photographer (possibly David Godlis).

Gift of artist to Diego Cortez. The 'Esoterrorists' were an imaginary NYC punk band consisting of Anya Phillips, Duncan Smith and Diego Cortez). They only existed as documented by various photos and published in art and music magazines and zines in 1978-79.

Gift of artist to Diego Cortez. This incarnation of the 'Esoterrorists' was as an imaginary Munich punk band consisting of Anya Phillips, Charlie Heil, Harald Vogl and Diego Cortez. These photos by Vogl remain unpublished.

did.unittitle: Andy Warhol, Diego Cortez and others
Anya Phillips, Tim Guest, Diego Cortez

scopecontent.p: Washington Square Park

did.physdesc: Stamped with artist's stamp and hand-notated as to series.

scopecontent.p: Gift of artist to Diego Cortez. Taken by Gruen at the Club Fez, in the East Village at a poetry reading in which all the subjects pictured read.

did.physdesc: Unsigned and mounted in window matte.

scopecontent.p: Six vintage Polaroids. Gift of artist to Diego Cortez. Cortez organized Basquiat's first solo gallery exhibition at Galleria Emilio Mazzoli, which opened May, 1981. Cortez accompanied Basquiat to Modena and installed the show. These were part of about 20 Polaroids Basquiat took in Modena's Piazza Grande during the installation period.
Man standing in front of a storefront
Woman and child
